story: NewsWoman asks for fashion advice with mirror selfie - but people spot something very rude in the photoFashion blogger Chloe Morello wasn't sure if her socks went with her outfit, but very few people ended up looking at her feet&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer15:45, 22 JUL 2018NewsChloe Morello is a popular blogger with millions of fans (Image: Chloe Morello/Instagram)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Chloe Morello is a successful blogger, so she normally knows what she's talking about when it comes to fashion and style.  But the 27-year-old wasn't completely sure about one of her outfits so asked her fans what they thought. She shared a mirror selfie showing her in a black vest top, a gold sequin mini skirt and some bright pink socks. The caption read: Guys, need your help! Do these socks ruin the outfit? At first glance, it looks like a lovely outfit. But then fans noticed a very rude addition.  It appears Chloe has marked a penis into the sequins on the skirt. Fans loved her cheeky post, and it's been liked more than 76,000 times. One wrote: Only kinda d*** pic i'd be ok to receive. Another added: I'm currently in the hospital and this picture literally made me laugh out loud.

title: afghanistan vice president dostum accused
story: NewsAfghanistan vice president Dostum narrowly escapes suicide bomber as he returns from exile despite being accused of tortureDostum, who left his country amid allegations of torturing a rival, had left the airport in a motorcade only minutes before the explosion&nbspShareByMirror15:13, 22 JUL 2018Updated15:32, 22 JUL 2018NewsKabul was rocked by a suicide blast as Vice President Dostum returned from exile (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfghan Vice President Abdul Rashid Dostum narrowly escaped a suspected suicide bomb attack at Kabul airport as he returned home on Sunday after more than a year in exile Dostum, who left his country amid allegations of torturing a rival, had left the airport in a motorcade only minutes before the explosion. Officials believed the blast, which left at least 11 dead, was carried out by a suicide bomber. Pictures showed the dead and wounded strewn across the road. Kabul police spokesman Hashmat Stanekzai said the blast went off near the main airport entrance, where supporters had been waiting to greet Dostum as his motorcade passed on its way to the city centre. The number of casualties may rise. The blast happened right after Dostum's convoy left the airport, he said.  Man is sentenced to death for rape of seven-month-old baby girl in latest case to horrify India    Millionaire's son hacked own family to death with an axe in a murder case that shocked the world  Dostum, an ethnic Uzbek veteran of decades of Afghanistan's bloody politics, was unharmed and greeted cheering supporters at a rally in his office compound. Much of the area around the presidential palace was shut down for the arrival and there was a heavy security presence on the streets, emphasising the increasingly volatile political climate in Kabul. Dostum faced outrage from Western donor countries including the United States, after reports in 2016 that his guards had seized political rival Ahmad Eshchi and subjected him to beatings, torture and violent sexual abuse. He denied Eshchi's accusations but, amid international demands that he be held accountable, he left the country in May last year, ostensibly to seek medical treatment in Turkey. Dostum is one of Afghanistan's most infamous figures, loved and loathed in equal measure. He is a notorious warlord who supported the West against the Taliban - but he is accused of committing numerous atrocities dating back decades.

title: aussie jesse curran aims to repay faith shown by dundee gaffer neil mccann
story: Dundee youngster Jesse Curran is out to repay Neil McCann’s faith in him as he aims to force his way into the first team at Dens Park.The 22-year-old just recently put pen to paper on a new one-year contract with the Dark Blues and appreciates the chance he’s been given by the club – one he’s desperate to grab with both hands.“Last season was probably the best season I’ve had in terms of playing in Dundee with the new manager coming in and giving me a chance,” he said.“I appreciate that and now just need to kick on this campaign and play as many games as I can and play well.“He’s had faith in me and I need to repay him by working hard and by doing the best I can.“The contract took a while to get sorted, get everything organised, so I was just happy to get it done when I got back.“It was hard keeping in contact being in Australia over the summer.“I’m happy it’s all signed and looking forward to the season.“The gaffer told me he wanted to keep me here and he was happy with me.”Curran made eight first-team appearances last season after just two the previous campaign and is keen to add to that number, starting this Sunday at home to Dunfermline.The young Aussie was mainly used as a right wing-back by gaffer Neil McCann, though, this season he’s preparing for a different role in the team.He said: “I started off in midfield but the gaffer sees me better with the game in front of me where I can run on to the play.“I played at wing-back last season but this campaign it’s all about right-back and trying to learn the position.“My main focus is defending – that’s what I need to work on and just go from there really.”Learning and hard work are key to Curran’s attitude and his down-to-earth nature has him looking up to another player who came up through the youth system at Dens Park.They’ve had completely different routes through their very early careers but Curran is keen to learn from his direct competition at right-back in Cammy Kerr.Kerr burst into the first team in 2016 after working his way up the age groups before making the right full-back position his own for the past couple of seasons.Keeping an eye on how Kerr goes about his work and picking up everything he can is key for Curran – as well as taking in everything he can from a whole range of voices at Dens Park.“I’d say Cammy Kerr is one of the best one-v-one defenders in the league,” Curran added.“I can obviously learn off him every day and get as much as I can just watching him. Even Darren O’Dea has been helping me with my defending and Graham Gartland has helped a lot and every day I’m trying to learn.“If my chance comes I’ll back myself to do the best I can.”Curran came off the bench in the 4-0 win over Stirling last weekend and is hoping to make it appearance No 2 nice and quickly against the Pars on Sunday.He added: “Dunfermline have always been a strong team in the Championship, always competing to get promotion to the Premiership so it will be a good test after they beat Peterhead 3-0 the other night.“There was a great turnout to the Stirling game so, hopefully, we’ll get another good one this weekend.”

title: betfred cup ties remain vital as dundee united work to get going
story: For Dundee United, this season’s Betfred Cup looks all but over but don’t trying telling stand-in skipper Stewart Murdoch the final two group fixtures are meaningless.The 28-year-old knows today&#8217s Tannadice clash with Alloa and next week’s trip to Elgin will be vital games as the Tangerines work to make sure they are a force in the coming Championship campaign.And while the ties so far against Arbroath and Ross County have ended in disappointment in terms of results, he believes they provided proof they’re heading in the right direction.“I think the thing is it’s really early doors and the manager will tell you we are still building, that’s maybe why we haven’t had the results we wanted,” he said.“We are still basically in a pre-season phase, so, for us, Tuesday was a really good competitive game up at County and gave us an opportunity to see exactly where we are right now.“It was another 90 minutes for the lads together and to help get to know each other. When you get the penalty at 0-0 and late on, if you score you probably go on and see out the game.“We didn’t and it was disappointing to lose but at the same time everybody could see the other night that already we can compete and we can take that forward. Now we move on to the next game.”And that need to be ready for next month’s league kick-off against Dunfermline means, for Murdoch and his team-mates, the next two outings are massive.“It will be difficult to qualify from our group now but we will take every game the same way we’ve always done and that’s as big ones.“We probably need to win both games now to have any chance and that’s what we’ll aim to do.“And they are another two big games leading into the start of the season in the Championship. We can get match sharpness and we will have another few boys who’ve had wee injuries back available.“It’s also another opportunity as well for the gaffer to maybe tinker with the team a bit and get boys some game time.”And, despite what the Betfred group table suggests, his belief this rebuilt United side is going to be a force to be reckoned with in the second tier, is growing.“I think everyone is confident we are building a good team and the manager will be wanting a few more players – I’m sure he’d said that.“I think the more good players we add the better we’ll play and the more we play together the better we’ll become.“It gave us confidence going to a place like County and competing the way we did. It was a good performance, it was just the result that was poor.“We are all excited about the season ahead and I think it’s going to be a positive one.”In the absence of newly-appointed club captain Fraser Fyvie, who’s likely to be out for another month or so as he completes his recovery from knee surgery at the turn of the year, the games so far have seen Murdoch wear the captain’s armband.Well aware of United’s history and some of the greats who’ve undertaken the role, he regards even having it on a temporary basis as a big feather in his cap.“I was captain a couple of times towards the end of last season and to be handed it again while Fraser is still out is nice,” he added.“This is a massive club, so to lead Dundee United out in any game is a huge honour for me.”

title: csaba laszlo urging dundee united to speed up
story: Csaba Laszlo wants Dundee United to speed up when their Betfred Cup campaign continues at home to Alloa today.Despite a draw and a penalty shoot-out loss against Arbroath and a narrow defeat at Ross County in the two group ties so far, Csaba has been pleased with the signs coming from his rebuilt Tangerines.The next step forward he wants to see, though, is quicker use of the ball leading to more chances being created.“If I watch the team, Matej Rakovan, Adam Barton, Christoph Rabitsch, Callum Booth and others, they are really good football players,” he said.“They keep the ball well and have some good ideas, but we have to do more in the offence.“You can’t just control the game, you also have to go and finish, bring more danger in front of the opponent’s goal, be quicker.“I told them that for the second half at Ross County, ‘OK we are comfortable with the ball but we have to bring more danger’.”Fraser Aird will be in the squad after he sat out the County trip.

title: dundee boss neil mccann says craig wighton needed half time telling off
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann revealed Craig Wighton needed a proverbial kick up the backside at half-time in the weekend victory at Stirling – and he won’t be letting him “rest on” his talent in the future either.After going in at the break 1-0 to the good, Wighton’s second-half performance did show more urgency, with the 20-year-old delivering a telling cross for Sofien Moussa’s second and a classy finish himself.That strike was the Scotland U/21 international’s first since a 5-1 win over Motherwell way back in February 2017 after a serious knee injury curtailed much of the last campaign.And his manager is looking forward to seeing what Wighton can bring to the side in the season ahead.Neil said: “I’m delighted for him. It’s taken him a lot of time.“He went away with Scotland U/21s but he’s looked really fit in pre-season and you can see the quality he has.“I had a wee go at him at half-time because, for me, he was sitting on it, resting.“I don’t like people resting on ability like that and I think second half he was much more of a threat.”The Dens boss has also revealed he will continue to rotate the captaincy in the upcoming games after Genseric Kusunga wore the armband at Stirling.“I think it’s good they all get a wee bit of a shot and feel they can hold that responsibility.“The armband really isn’t that important to me so I’ll probably continue to do that throughout the League Cup.”

title: dundee fans and tottenham teammates turn out to pay respects to football legend alan gilzean
story: Fans and former teammates paid tribute to Dundee icon Alan Gilzean on Friday as the legendary striker made his final journey past Dens Park.Supporters young and old braved the rain as the hearse carrying the title-winning forward drove up Sandeman Street just before midday.The ex-Dark Blues and Tottenham Hotspur star died earlier this month aged 79, just weeks after being diagnosed with a brain tumour.Among those to attend his funeral at Dundee Crematorium were several of his ex-Spurs teammates, including Pat Jennings and Alan Mullery.About 80 supporters gathered outside the stadium to pay their respects.Mark Kerr, 64, originally from Lochee, travelled down from Inverness to bid farewell to Mr Gilzean, who he said was one of his heroes.He said: “I was at Dens when Dundee won the league.“I was seven years old and I remember it distinctly.“I watched him playing in Europe and it confirmed I wanted to be a Dundee supporter for life.“I saw Alan at a hall of fame dinner at the Invercarse recently, so I was shocked to hear of his passing.“I’m the chairman of the Highland Dark Blues. I’ve come down from Inverness to pay my respect, and I’ll be raising a drink in his memory tonight.”Born in Coupar Angus, Gilzean is considered one of the finest players to grace Dens Park and netted an unrivalled 169 goals during the halcyon days of the 1950s and 60s.His eye for a goal was a crucial factor in Dundee’s title-winning season in 1961-62, before the club went on to reach the semi-final of the European Cup.Season ticket holder George McLaren, 73, said: “He has been such a big part of Dundee FC. My favourite memories of him are probably the goals against Dundee United.“I was shocked to hear of his passing and wanted to come here today to pay my respects. He will never be forgotten. He proved himself here at Dens and at Spurs.“An absolute legend for both clubs.”Fellow fan Daniel Smith, 33, from Maryfield, added: “There’s been a good turnout of people paying their respects here today at Dens.“He is a Dundee legend. I grew up on stories about Gilzean through the years and the things he accomplished at Dens. He still holds a number of records at Dens Park.”A tribute on the Dundee FC website stated: “Everyone at Dundee Football Club was devastated to learn of the death of Dundee legend Alan Gilzean aged 79 after a short illness.“A true Dundee legend in every sense of the word, we may never see his goal scoring like again and the thoughts of everyone at Dens Park are with Alan’s family and friends at this difficult and sad time.”He made the jump from Tayside to Tottenham in 1964 for a £72,500 fee, lifting two League Cups, the FA Cup and the UEFA Cup.As well as the dark blue of Dundee, Hall of Famer Gilzean earned 22 Scotland caps between 1963 and 1971, bagging 12 goals.

title: dundee kiltwalk stet for biggest year as 2000 signed up
story: Dundee&#8217s Kiltwalk is set for its biggest year yet — with all the signs pointing towards a record number of walkers for 2018.Paul Cooney, chief executive of the Kiltwalk, said the number of sign-ups was close to 2,000 with four weeks to go until the big day — almost the same number of people who took part last year.He met up with members of the Tay Road Bridge Joint Board and Dundee United midfielder Scott Allardice to launch the new start point of the five-mile Wee Wander.It’s one of three routes walkers can choose to complete, and follows the banks of the Tay from the refreshed urban art space underneath the road bridge to Monifieth.All three walks take place on Sunday August 19 — with the start points at the Tay Road Bridge, Tayport and St Andrews — and any registered charity can be supported.At the end of the Kiltwalk, all funds raised are given a massive 40% boost by the Hunter Foundation, run by philanthropist Sir Tom Hunter.The Kiltwalk takes no cut of the cash raised — instead funding the events through registration fees, which means every penny raised goes direct to good causes.Paul said: “Dundee has been brilliant with us. This year, we’re closing in on 2,000 people with four weeks to go, and last year we had 2,000 people taking part.“It’s a brilliant way of raising money for your chosen charity. We’re very lucky to have Sir Tom Hunter supporting us, boosting your fund by 40%.“It’s a great way of raising un-restricted funds for local charities.“People still ask what causes they can support and the answer is simply any registered charity — and they will all get the 40%.“There’s still time to sign up but if you’re thinking of doing the 25-mile walk, I’d start training now.”The Tele is continuing backing Dundee’s Kiltwalk as a great way of raising money for good causes across Tayside — a fact that has not gone unnoticed.Paul added: “I have to thank the Evening  and its readers for their support.“It’s made such a difference for us and I can’t overstate the importance of DC Thomson, and the Evening  especially, to what we do here in Dundee.”United star Scott added: “It’s all for a good cause and it’s not every day you can say you’ve been for a walk of up to 25 miles. I’m keeping my fingers crossed for everyone that we get good weather.”As part of its partnership with the Tay Road Bridge Joint Board, the Kiltwalk team devised a road bridge ‘takeover’.Bridge staff have hung flags and banners promoting the Kiltwalk along the length of the crossing.Bridge manager Alan Hutchison said: “With the new space available to all the people of Dundee and the wider community it made sense to lend it to the Kiltwalk.”West End Liberal Democrat councillor and joint board member Fraser Macpherson said: “We’re all very supportive of the Kiltwalk and all the funds it raises for charities across Scotland.“It’s great to see the bridge staff taking such a proactive approach to getting involved and it’s fantastic that there’s such great support for it here in Dundee.”There’s still time to sign up for Dundee’s Kiltwalk — go online to thekiltwalk to find out more.

title: dundee people alyx set for world stage
story: A Monifieth street dancer is to represent Scotland on the world stage.Alyx Gray, 11, is through to the under-12 beginner/novice category at the UDO World Championships at the Hydro in Glasgow.She will also represent the country at the European Championships in the Netherlands next year.Alyx qualified after becoming Scottish champion.The former Seaview Primary pupil, who starts at Monifieth High this year, began dancing aged seven.She is coached by Laura Nisbet, who runs the Addicted 2 Dance studio in Dundee.Mum Jody said: “We are chuffed to bits. She has done us proud and has worked extremely hard.”Established in 2002, UDO is the world’s largest international street dance organisation.

title: dundee people asda ace jim checks out for the last time
story: Asda Ace Jim Dodds has checked out of work for the last time.Jim was a war baby born in 1941 but 77 years later the former roofer is only just putting his feet up.The great-grandfather started his working life in Dundee’s jute mills before becoming a roofer.He even helped to build his future workplace at Asda Kirkton more than 40 years ago.Jim and his wife Patricia, of Whitfield, have four daughters and two sons.Their family also now includes 15 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.One of Jim’s daughters, Debbie, even followed in his footsteps when she also became an Asda Ace and went on to work on the checkouts.Jim spent 15 years as an Asda Ace and for the last few years has been responsible for keeping the bakery and deli in tip-top condition.Samantha Will, community champion at Asda Kirkton, organised a special retirement lunch for the much-loved colleague.Jim was given a new set of wheels – in the shape of an inflatable walking frame.Debbie said: “My dad doesn’t actually want to give up work but it is time for him to go.“He was surprised by the retirement lunch – he didn’t think they were going to do anything for him.“My dad has never been unemployed. Both him and my mum have always worked so I don’t know what he is going to do with himself now.”Samantha said: “Jim is a familiar face in Asda Kirkton and always has a smile for everyone.“He is loved by all of the staff here and we will miss him tremendously.”Jim loves taking bus tours, and with plenty of spare time now on his hands, he is heading to the Highlands with Patricia for a short holiday.After all his hard work at Asda, he certainly deserves it.

title: dundee people asda staff do summit special for charity
story: The fantastic staff at Asda Kirkton have once again done their bit for local charities.A group of 11 employees of the store climbed to the summit of Ben Nevis – a feat they achieved with the help of various local organisations.Samantha Will, community champion at the supermarket, said: “Some of us were given waterproofs by Ancrum Outdoor Centre and Dundee Sea Cadets drove us there and back in their minibus.“The sea cadets also provided a volunteer driver, Rachel, who was our angel for the day.“She picked us up at 6am on Sunday morning and we got back at 1am on Monday.“It was a long day but she didn’t complain once.“We are so very grateful for their help and we would all like to thank them for their generosity.”The walkers raised more than £2,000 through their endeavours.

title: dundee people joshua leaves behind a bit of dundee united for kids in malawi
story: Dundee United fan Joshua Grant is set to leave a little bit of Tannadice behind when he wraps up a school trip to Malawi.Joshua flew out to the African country as part of a trip organised by Stewart’s Melville College in Edinburgh and has given the kids he has been helping a set of Dundee United tops.Joshua’s brother and fellow Arab Callum shared a snap of Joshua with a group of kids on social media.He wrote: “My brother’s currently in Malawi helping children and he has taken Dundee United tops for all the kids to keep and enjoy.“Hopefully there is now another group of United fans in Malawi!“And long live the Arabs #P2BAA (Proud To Be An Arab).”

title: dundee people manjeet retires after 22 years
story: After 22 years of service, Manjeet Grill, co-ordinator at The Corner Dundee, a health and information service, is retiring.Starting out as a sessional worker encouraging young people from minority ethnic backgrounds to access citywide health services, she became an assistant project leader and then co-ordinator in 2011.Manjeet said: “Over the years I have been part of many changes at The Corner.“One of its successes is to be able to adapt, evolve and be responsive to young people’s needs. The Corner always has a multi-professional team which brings mixed skills to enable us to respond to the complexity of the needs of young people.”

title: dundee people photo exhibitionbrings dundee life into focus
story: A photography exhibition has been unveiled showcasing Dundee life in the modern era.Red Sky Photography’s survey of Dundee is the result of a full year of work by a dozen local shutterbugs, who snapped 5,500 frames of city living throughout 2017.The collective has captured a snapshot of the city frozen in time – celebrating its people, its new-found cultural relevance and much of its architecture, old and new.The full selection of images now forms a permanent collection in Dundee Libraries’ Local History Department, joining previous surveys carried out in 1991 and 1916.About 40 of those were hand-picked by Red Sky to create an exhibition that will be on show in Central Library until next week and later tour libraries around the city.Dundee-born Ian Crighton, one of the photographers involved in the project, said the group was given free rein in choosing what they captured.“It was a fairly open process as we set about the survey. We just captured events and places that we thought were significant,” he said.“There are photos of people, of events, the arts, dance activities, things such as the New Year’s Day Dook and a lot of buildings that we thought either were significant or would become significant.“I was given access to Dens Park, for example, because I imagine in 10 years or so it might no longer exist as we know it.“I’m quite surprised at what we’ve been able to achieve.”The Tele was given access to some of the archive and the differences in city life now and then are stark.The 1916 survey features street scenes in the city centre and atop the Hilltown – and couldn’t be any more different from the snaps from 1991.Many of the later images show the city at its post-industrial peak, complete with questionable fashion choices and a City Square yet to be pedestrianised.Red Sky’s modern day survey is packed with sights that are likely to be familiar now – the new railway station entrance under construction, rusted-in tram rails on the Murraygate and dance performances in front of Caird Hall.Rather topically, there are also photos of William Halley’s mill – now reduced to rubble.Alistair Wilson, of Dundee Libraries, said the relevance of these photographic surveys becomes very clear after just a few years, giving people a fresh perspective on a city that might have changed without them really noticing.“The 1991 survey was carried out by Dundee Photographic Society. It and the other surveys act like a social record of how the city was at that time,” he said.“Looking back at 1991, which doesn’t feel that long ago, you can see so many things have changed – the way people dress, the jobs they have, even the cars on the streets.“Once the exhibition finishes the plan is that it will move about so everyone can see it.”

title: dundee united set to announce signing eleventh signing of the summer
story: Dundee United are set to unveil former Falkirk defender Paul Watson.The 27-year-old will be Csaba Laszlo&#8217s eleventh signing of the summer.Watson made 49 appearances for the Bairns in a three-year spell before being released by Paul Hartley at the end of last season.The centre back made 24 appearances last season &#8211 including Falkirk&#8217s 6-1 mauling of United in January.More soon&#8230

title: future dundee football stars hoping to score from community chest
story: Broughty United 2012, a football team for children in primary one and two, is aiming to net some funds from the Tele’s Community Chest.The group currently has about 20 kids and six coaches who attend training and playing sessions but is encouraging more to join.Fundraising co-ordinator Kris Stuart said: “The team is for anyone born in 2012.“This is the first year of Dundee Community Sport which is hoping to get children trying different sports.“Currently, 20 kids play Fun Fours at Dundee International Sports Centre on a Saturday morning.“It is aimed at encouraging kids, giving them the experience of being part of a team and getting the feel of it, keeping them active and slowly bringing them into football.”The youngsters will take part in Fun Fours for two years before progressing onwards.The team is affiliated to Broughty United Youth Football Club as part of a youth development scheme run by Dundee City Council.The team’s first strips were supplied by the club and it has been raising funds for training gear and also received sponsorship towards another set.Kris said the youngsters and their families were enthusiastically collecting Community Chest tokens from the Tele.He added: “If we are successful in securing some funds, the money will go towards training kit and different equipment to allow us to coach the kids.“Equipment needed could include balls, cones, different goal sets, running ladders – all the stuff we need to get them going.“Opportunities such as this enable us to try to get some extra funding.“Token collecting has been going well and members’ families are also contributing.“The kids are really enjoying it.”To be in with a chance of winning a share of £10,000 in the Community Chest giveaway, all you need to do is collect at least 50 tokens by Saturday July 28.Don’t miss out on your chance for your non-profit community group to win some cash.Enter via thetele/promotions today.

title: give alan gilzean a proper dens park send off says dundee ace cammy kerr
story: Dundee favourite Cammy Kerr has called on the club’s supporters to give Alan Gilzean the send off the Dens legend deserves this weekend.The Dark Blues take on Dunfermline this Sunday in the first home game since Gilzean passed away at the age of 79.The club legend’s funeral takes place tomorrow and Sunday’s clash promises to be one full of emotion for everyone associated with Dundee.A special matchday programme will be available while there will be a minute’s silence and black armbands worn by the players but Kerr expects a bumper home crowd to give Gilzean a roaring send-off.The 22-year-old said: “It’s a terrible thing to happen.“Sadly, I never got to see him play or have the privilege of meeting him but what a figure to have played at this football club.“To know you are at the same football club as some of the greatest footballers have played at is fantastic.“I’d like to send my regards and best wishes to his family at this time, obviously a tough time.“In terms of the game, I think it will be emotional and, hopefully, the crowd turn out for a very special player for this football club.“I’ve read a few of things in the papers about the player he was and I actually remember watching the thing on TV at White Hart Lane when they closed the old stadium.“I knew he was a good player but I didn’t know how big he was for Tottenham.“When they said ‘The Original King of White Hart Lane, Alan Gilzean’ it just shows the regard he was held in down there.“Naming a lounge after him doesn’t do him justice because he was, obviously, a great talent.”Being a fan himself, Kerr knows the kind of supporters Dundee have and the loyalty they show their team – something he experienced in a very noisy welcome and send-off at last week’s friendly against Farense in Portugal.“We could hear them when we got off the bus in Albufeira but you can’t see how many there were,” Kerr added.“At the end I got a few photos and things and they were singing away.“The best bit was when we were leaving and they were all banging on the bus – it was great!“You see European games and all the fans waiting on the buses so it felt like that, it felt great.“For the fans to go across there just shows the loyalty that they’ll go across to Portugal for a friendly. That’s fantastic to see.“I gave away a pair of my boots and I think someone had them on running about the streets about 10 minutes later!”Allan Johnston’s Pars side will be looking to spoil Dundee’s return to the newly-named Kilmac Stadium at Dens Park by putting themselves into pole position in Betfred Cup Group D.And Kerr knows the Dark Blues will have to be right on their game to see off a Dunfermline side that swept past Peterhead in midweek.He added: “The game is on the TV as well which is good and the pitch is coming on really well, too. The groundsmen do a great job to give us a good pitch.“It’s always good to come out and have a game on the TV, it’s exciting, but Dunfermline are a side that will definitely try to push this year.“They’ve made some really important signings throughout their side and they’ll be a really tough test, so we’ll have to be firing on all cylinders.”

title: inspirational dundee woman chelsea hoping mentor others and help to change their lives
story: She is the inspirational young woman whose harrowing open letter to her drug addict parents thrust her on to the national stage and led to her sharing a platform with the first minister.Now Young Scot of the Year Chelsea Cameron wants to use her experiences to mentor others and offer them the chance to do life-changing voluntary work.Chelsea, 20, a former head girl at Menzieshill High School, made headlines in January last year after she wrote to mum Tammy and dad Alexander about her upbringing in Menzieshill.Chelsea with First Minister Nicola SturgeonShe described her parents’ behaviour and the devastating impact drug addiction could have on families.Her life has changed dramatically since then and now she wants other young people to be given experiences and skills to build themselves a future.Chelsea, who works as a PA, said: “I’m looking to informally mentor and give a voluntary opportunity to a young person between the ages of 16-20.“If it turns out that I get a huge response I will need to sit down and work out how to make the selection.“It may be possible to take on more than one young person initially – maybe a boy and a girl.“Over the past year I’ve had so many opportunities to attend great events and meet so many incredible people that I used to think were so far out of my reach.“As Young Scot of the Year, I’m committed to helping another young person to have opportunities to broaden their horizons and realise the world is their oyster.“I attend many events ranging from speaking to young people, policy makers, politicians and everything in between – there was even royalty once.”Chelsea added: “I have given this a lot of thought and would love to hear from people who think they would like to take up this opportunity.“I feel a responsibility to do something to help someone else in the way I have been helped.“Along the way, I’d hope this young person develops self- confidence, good communication, presentation and public speaking skills, time management and how to prioritise.“This is a fantastic chance to develop some skills and build networking opportunities that can be advantageous for future employment.“All of this is combined with lots of fun and plenty of chocolate cake. If I can give another young person the opportunities I’ve been given, why would I pass it up?”Chelsea said she would love to identify a suitable candidate by next month.She added: “I have a lot of events coming up soon and would like the young person to be with me in time for these.“All travel and any other expenses will be provided.”Chelsea said she wasn’t sure what the response to her offer would be but she was hopeful young people would get in touch.“First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has already supported my offer, as have some other MSPs and other high profile personalities and charities,” she said.“If this is something you would love to do, please send a short piece about yourself and why you feel this would be a good opportunity for you to Chelsea-cameron@hotmail.”After her letter was made public, Chelsea was invited to London to appear on television and radio, beginning with the Victoria Derbyshire show.She was also interviewed on various news programmes and within a week her story had gone viral worldwide.Among those who were touched by the letter was Ms Sturgeon, who invited Chelsea to meet her for coffee and a chat.

title: kharl madianga set to make first dundee start
story: With midfielder Glen Kamara expected to be missing for Dundee this weekend, Kharl Madianga is expected to get his first chance from the start against Dunfermline.The Dark Blues host the Pars in Betfred Cup Group D on Sunday with Finnish international Kamara a big doubt after a training-ground clash left him with a protective boot on his foot.The club are hoping the damage is minimal and the use of the boot is purely a precaution.However, it’s unlikely he’ll be risked for the weekend game with Allan Johnston’s side.That means French midfielder Madianga is in line for a first competitive start since signing for the club over the summer.The former French U/17 international joined the club from Bulgarian side Lokomotiv GO – the same side Sofien Moussa was signed from.He made his competitive debut for the Dark Blues last weekend in the 4-0 victory at Stirling Albion, coming off the bench for fellow-new boy Elton Ngwatala.And manager Neil McCann said after that game Madianga was one Dundee fans should look forward to seeing in action.“Kharl came on and showed glimpses as well, he’s a fantastic player so in the midfield I think we have some real exciting talent in there,” the Dens gaffer said.Also missing at the moment for Dundee is winger Roarie Deacon.He’s continuing his recovery from ankle surgery and is expected to be out for a while yet.Club skipper Darren O’Dea missed the win at Stirling last week, and two friendlies in Portugal the previous week, with a groin problem.

title: local girl trampled on by horse fundraises for air ambulance
story: A brave schoolgirl who was trampled by a horse at Kirriemuir Show has started fundraising for the Scottish Charity Air Ambulance (SCAA).Charlotte Stork, 11, who starts at Webster’s High School after the summer, had finished competing on her pony Robin at the show when another horse backed on to her.The youngster suffered a head and leg injury and the SCAA was scrambled.After checks, it was decided Charlotte could be taken by road to Ninewells Hospital, where she was kept for observation until 9.30pm.Charlotte has now donated her £12 prize money to the Scone-based charity and a link on her mother Jane’s Facebook page has already raised another £200.Jane was full of praise for the emergency teams and show organisers who sprang into action at the showground.She said: “We are not blaming anyone, it was just one of those things.“Two horses got into a fight, one backed away and trampled on her.”

title: quirky home planned for old iconic dundee pie shop site
story: A famous Dundee pie shop bakery left to decay for more than 40 years is to be transformed into a quirky new home.The Auld Dundee Pie Shop at 18-20 Castle Street, which served up the famous Wallace peh, was a household name in the city from the turn of the 20th Century until it closed down in the late 1970s.Owned by David Wallace, it was once part of a string of pie shops run by the family, also featuring a restaurant named Wallace’s Tea Rooms.Dundee-based Castle Development has now been granted planning permission to convert the C-listed bakehouse at the back of the former shop and tearooms into a two-bedroom home.The development will add to the ongoing conversion of the adjacent St Paul’s Church, which is being transformed from a pub into residential accommodation.The business originally opened in 1892 in the Vault under the Caird Hall, an area now being converted into trendy restaurants such as the recently-opened Brassica.In the early 1920s Mr Wallace moved to the building on Castle Street, when the Vault was due for demolition, as the building was big enough to open the tearoom as well as the two-floor bakehouse.During the Second World War it is reported the queues for pies and bridies used to stretch down to the bottom of the street as they were able to supplement the meat ration. Now hidden from street view, the bakehouse has not been used since it closed 41 years ago, in 1977.A pend between two shops allows access from the street, which then opens up into a large courtyard and the entrance to the bakery.A design statement submitted by RDA Architects, on behalf of Castle Development, says the history of the building will be incorporated.It states: “The proposals seek to highlight the historic elements on the replacement elevation highlighting the area from which the dilapidation began, visibly documenting the history of the site and ensuring the preservation of the remaining structure.“The materials have been carefully considered against the context of the former bakery, its perceived history and gradual dilapidation and eventual demolition of its western elevation.”

title: stirling albion or celtic its all the same to dundee new boy jean mendy
story: In his very short time at Dundee, Senegalese striker Jean Mendy has already shown he can get fans off their seats at Dens Park this season.And he plans to continue doing that – as well as getting goals – whether he’s playing against Stirling Albion or Celtic, it’s all the same to him.He told the Tele: “I don’t know the teams at the moment!“For me, playing Stirling is like playing against Celtic, it’s the same for me – I just play my game, it doesn’t matter, and try to win every game.”The 28-year-old was delighted to start his career in dark blue with a goal after he knocked in a good strike from the edge of area as his new team began the season with a morale-boosting 4-0 victory at Stirling Albion.“It was good and we won of course – it’s very important to start winning,” Mendy added.“It was a little bit hot, I think, on the pitch on Saturday, we could feel it.“The performance was good, can be better you know, it was the first game but it was good to get the confidence with this game.“It was great for the team to score a lot of goals and we have shown we have people who can score.“I was pleased to get the goal, I got the chance and I put it in.“It was perfect for me to start with a goal and good for my confidence so I’m very happy to start like this.”Mendy joined the club from Belgian top-flight side Lokeren where he struggled to make an impact.That was after piling in the goals in the Norwegian lower leagues.Back in 2012, he banged in 27 goals in 25 league games for Elverum in the third tier before 27 in 52 in the next tier for Kristiansund. A move up to the top flight only brought a return of six in 23 for Sandefjord before returning to Kristiansund and then getting the big move to Belgium.Manager Neil McCann said he’d been keeping an eye on Mendy’s progress after missing out on him when he departed Norway.He’s finally got his man and the forward is delighted to be at Dundee, even if he’s not spent much time in the city with the club spending a week-long training camp in Portugal.He said: “I’ve enjoyed my time so far, it’s a good club with good players, too, and I think this year will be a good one.“Portugal was a lot of training. That sort of preparation is normal and it was good for us but you feel it when we played the games over there.“We didn’t get the wins in the friendlies, maybe one win against Sunderland but we lost the last two but they were only friendlies – more important is winning the games when the season begins, like Saturday.“It was very good to show we are ready.“There are a few new players, myself as well, and it’s very important for us to get together with the team and start to know each other in training, talk together and know how we all play.“It’s looking good. We’ll obviously continue to work more but I think the season will be good.”After starting off Group D with victory, Mendy and his new team-mates take on Dunfermline at home in front of the television cameras on Sunday.Even if he doesn’t know much about his opponents just yet, Mendy knows the Dundee fans will be expecting a good show from their side and he’s hoping to add to his goal tally.“I’m looking forward to my first home game this weekend.“That will be very important in front of our supporters.“Of course, we want to play a good game, put on a show for the fans and win the game, too.“We are going for a victory.”

title: Dancer is all smiles after major Canada win
story: &nbspA HIGHLAND dancing champion has scooped one of her highest accolades yet after triumphing in an international dance competition.Lily Kelman (11) is a member of the Fraser School of Highland Dance and travelled to the ScotDance Canada Championships Series in Calgary, Alberta recently, where she took on fellow dancers from all over the world.Clearly not fazed by the competition she was ultimately named Open Canadian Champion for her age group.The competition was her fifth championship event and she won all three categories she entered &ndash Highland competition, Premiership National Championship and Open Highland Championship.This latest victory followed on from a runner-up spot at the SDTA Central Scotland Championshps earlier this year, an impressive placing that was itself followed by her first Open Championship title secured at the UK Alliance Championships in Edinburgh, in which she saw off 33 other top competitors.Her younger sister Grace (9) also competed in the Canadian event, in the intermediate section, and came home with five medals.Provost Helen Carmichael had met both girls before they set off across the Atlantic and was delighted to welcome them back to Inverness Town House this week."Lily is an excellent example of what our young people can achieve with commitment and sheer endeavour," she said."While I congratulate Lily on her personal achievements I also commend the role that she is playing through her participation in international Highland dance competitions as a young ambassador for Inverness and the Highlands."She added: "Before Lily and Grace left for Canada, I was delighted to donate Inverness Town House pin badges to both girls so that they could take part in the pin exchange which took place at the start of the championship series."The girls acted as ambassadors for Inverness, exchanging pins between dancers of many different nationalities."Lily' mother Yvonne said: "A staggering 980 dancers were entered into the ScotDance competition as a whole and from that 10 girls in total came from Inverness &ndash&nbsp seven from the Claire Bryce School of Highland Dance and three from the Fraser School of Dance, both Inverness."All girls did amazingly well and came home with a haul of medals and trophies."Monday 23 Jul 2018 3:34 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Inverness pub submits plans for new street cafe by the castle
story: &nbspA POPULAR pub close to Inverness Castle has applied for permission to build a new street caf&eacute nearby.The owners of the Castle Tavern want to take over a small plot of landscaped land just a stone' throw from its premises in View Place.Owner Jane Wilson said efforts had been made to trace the owners of the land, to enquire about buying or leasing it, but ownership "cannot be determined".The area is currently maintained by Highland Council but she said staff at the pub also worked to keep it tidy and litter-free.In a statement to support the application, she says: "This piece of land forms part of the adopted road and, as such, we have lodged an application for permission to occupy the road with a street caf&eacute."Given its proximity to an area of the town that has so much tourist interest, we feel we could make use of the land and that this would benefit visitors to the town as well as our business."The Castle Tavern is located across from the end and beginning of the Great Glen Way and, as such, we have a large number of visitors - walkers and cyclists."The beer garden that we have is small and we are limited in how many cycles we can accommodate. The only other place for them is on the footpath. This can cause restricted use of the path for pedestrians and customers."Our plans for the area are to tidy it up and improve the landscaping, insert some tables and benches and a secure area for housing bicycles."The plot, she added, would be serviced by the Castle Tavern' CCTV and be maintained to a high standard.There are also possible longer-term plans to install a charging point for electric bikes."The use of this land would be mainly seasonal as we do not intend to put any building on it and it would be used primarily for visitors who currently cycle or walk the Great Glen Way," she said.Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister said she thought it was a "wonderful" idea for tourists and residents alike."It will be perfect for when the weather is nice and people want to sit outside for their meals," she said."The Castle Tavern is always very busy, especially their outside area."Cllr McAllister wants to encourage more restaurants and bars to utilise outdoor areas as long as they are able to ensure that people with disabilities are not impacted."In Inverness our streets can be quite narrow, so it has to be done properly," she said.Glad to hear that the move by the Castle Tavern could benefit cyclists, she added: "The more bikes on the roads in Inverness the better the quality of air for everyone."Monday 23 Jul 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Inverness street closures ahead of Highland Games
story: THE Inverness Highland Games take place on Saturday at Bught Park.The programme, however, will start on Friday with the Inverness Gala evening including the Inverness Wheelbarrow Grand Prix, organised by Inverness Culloden Rotary Club, and performances in the High Street by the City of Inverness Pipe Band, the Elizabeth Fraser School of Highland Dancing and the Inverness branch of the Royal Scottish Country Dance Association.There will also be a parade across Ness Bridge to the Northern Meeting Park at 7pm where the Highlands' Strongest Man and Strongest Woman Championships organised by the Forge Gym will take place.As part of these events a number of city centre streets will be closed between 6.50pm and 7.25pm on Friday evening.Closures planned are as follows:1. title: New 40k artwork unveiled for Ness Islands
story: &nbspA &pound40,000 artwork which would enable children to paddle in and enjoy the water at the Ness Islands is the latest offering from the Inverness River Connections project.&nbspIf approved by councillors, it will consist of patterned sculptural stepping stones made of granite, sitting in a stainless steel channel or lade.Water from the river will feed into this channel where some of the stones will be fitted with moveable sluice gates to allow children to control the flow of water themselves.The plan is for it to be located in the middle of the Ness Islands at a spot already popular with families.The proposal is just one element of the River Ness Public Art Project, worth a total of &pound727,000.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael was yesterday hopeful that the concept would find favour with councillors on Highland Council' south planning committee, especially since local schoolchildren had been consulted on what they would like to see there, and Inverness College UHI design students had input on the concept.She said: "Children were very involved along with students at the university. Children love jumping from stone to stone and guddling about in water."It has all been looked at from the safety point of view, but let' face it, if you take children to the beach they jump from stone to stone. I think it is a good project and if necessary I will be the first to dip my toe in the water there."Inverness city manager David Haas said: "This has had youth engagement all along and I think it is something that is going to sit well in the environment of a place that will become even more popular as people engage with the river."Masterminding the project is Bespoke Atelier, a Glasgow-based design studio.Its design statement, which will be discussed at a planning meeting later this summer, explains the lades and weirs already around the River Ness were used as inspiration. The stones would be patterned, partly to minimise slips and also to reflect foliage patterns from trees growing on the islands.A report from Inverness City Artworks Group states: "While it was preferable to use natural stone, the cost might prove prohibitive and alternative materials might need to be considered."It was also minuted that if concerns were raised regarding the cost of this feature, the high cost of "providing basic play equipment should be highlighted."The group was given assurances that the design would, when completed, look like part of the landscape, and members were told that Bespoke Atelier was confident that all aspects of the design could be met within the available budget.Path improvements in the vicinity are included in the application.Company director Yvonne Elliot-Kellighan said the stepping stone forms envisaged were inspired by the shape of the Ness Islands, and the stones themselves could be engraved with botanical patterns "creating a ow and connection between stepping stones".The children' feature is not far from MY Ness, a &pound300,000 centrepiece which was unveiled as a concept in May and has still to receive planning permission.The River Ness Public Art Project is funded by Creative Scotland (&pound305,000), Inverness Common Good Fund (&pound250,000), HIE (&pound66,000) and Highland Council (&pound106,000).At a time of heightened concern about public spending, Highland Council has stressed that the vast majority of the money for the projects comes from third parties and cannot be used for other purposes, and the council' &pound106k is from capital investment and not revenue spend.Monday 23 Jul 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: New cinema proposed for the Black Isle
story: &nbspA THRIVING film society on the Black Isle looks set to take its next big step after plans were submitted for a permanent cinema to cater for growing demand.The brand new cinema, which would be located on the seafront in Cromarty, will cater to Cromarty and Resolis Film Society events and serve as a base for the town' increasingly popular annual film festival.Cromarty Estate, which owns the land, has lodged the application in partnership the film society, which would act as its tenant.The plans feature two key elements. The first is the cinema, which would be built on land close to the ferry slipway and next to an existing boat storage shed.The cinema would seat roughly 30 people and host weekly screenings throughout the year, rising to twice a week in the summer. It would also be used to help house Cromarty' growing film festival, which attracts fans and famous faces from across the country late every autumn.Cromarty Estate also plans to build an office hub alongside the cinema in a bid to cater for growing business demand in the town.In a supporting statement submitted by the estate alongside its application, its agents said: "A dedicated cinema space will allow screening all year which currently is not possible using existing buildings with poor black out facilities."The cinema may also be available for other users to hire for screenings, presentations and lectures."They added that the cinema would also "ideally" feature an outdoor area "for summer screenings and festival events".Making the case for new office space in the town, the estate said: "Cromarty has a thriving entrepreneurial community but this is not matched by suitable office accommodation with the result that many find themselves having to move their business bases from Cromarty to Dingwall, Tore or Inverness when they outgrow their own homes, with the resulting loss of employment opportunities in the town."Addressing this need... will make Cromarty a more balanced and sustainable community."In a statement supporting the application, the film society said that a survey of Cromarty residents found that 82 per cent backed a cinema in the town and the same number would go to more screenings if the venue was better than what is currently on offer.Justifying the decision to proceed with an all-new site for the cinema, the estate' agents said the site' position close to adequate parking and its location away from homes were both positives, as was the existing vehicle access from the harbour.The buildings would feature dark metal cladding to the walls of the cinema, with timber cladding on the office hub.If the plans are approved construction could start as early as spring next year.Monday 23 Jul 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Party raises thousands to help brave toddler Leo
story: &nbspA FUNDRAISING party in support of an "incredible" three-year-old with an incurable condition raised more than &pound11,300.Members of the audience were moved to tears as they listened to the story of Leo Flett, a toddler from Balloch with a rare form of muscular dystrophy, who "manages a smile even at his lowest points".His parents, Louise and Mitchell, organised the event at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness to raise funds for scientific research into type 1C muscular dystrophy, a version of the muscle-wasting condition which affects fewer than 500 people across Britain.Around 250 people attended and funds were raised through ticket sales and auctions.Mrs Flett said he was "blown away" by people' generosity."The funds will be split between research and helping Leo to have the best quality of life," she said."I cannot thank everyone enough for coming along, donating prizes and helping us to fundraise." They are now working towards a sponsored climb of Ben Nevis on August 11 which will be led by fitness instructor Kevin Campbell.Since launching their appeal in January, the family have raised around &pound19,000 for the Leo' Pride fund."Leo is the bravest boy I have ever met and he brings so much happiness to our lives," Mrs Flett added.To donate, visit www.justgiving/campaigns/charity/muscular-dystrophy/leospridefundMonday 23 Jul 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Poignant anniversary to be marked by Loch Ness Marathon
story: &nbspLEADING veterans&rsquo charities have joined forces with the Baxters Loch Ness Marathon to mark 100 years since the end of WWI.Poppyscotland, along with its sister organisation Legion Scotland, will form a team of 100 runners for the event to raise money for ex-service personnel and honour the landmark anniversary.The charities are now welcoming applications to join "Team Centurion Poppy," the name given to the runners competing in aid of veterans.Kevin Gray MM, chief executive of Legion Scotland, has urged runners to sign up.He said: "Legion Scotland is delighted to support our sister charity Poppyscotland in raising funds to continue their full range of welfare services for those in need in the Armed Forces community throughout the country."We are reaching out to the organisers of the Loch Ness Marathon and to our many supporters to help us gather a team of 100 runners to form the Legion Scotland Team Centurion Poppy."The team will be made up of runners of mixed abilities, from those who want to be part of a fun-filled day in Inverness, to the seasoned athlete hoping to break a personal best, but all wanting to make a difference to those in need."We aim to raise &pound1918 as part of the Poppyscotland &lsquoPoppy Pledge&rsquo, but we want to smash that target, and we believe with public support we will turn this dream into a reality."Time to register for the race&nbsp is now upon us and people will need time to train so we are urging everyone to&nbsp come and join our team on September 23rd."The Baxters Loch Ness Marathon' race director Malcolm Sutherland said: "We are absolutely delighted to have Team Centurion Poppy running in the Baxters Loch Ness Marathon this year."We are very grateful to Poppyscotland and Legion Scotland for championing 100 runners for 100 years and suggesting our marathon to bring everyone together for this great cause."The Loch Ness Marathon follows a spectacular point-to-point route alongside world famous Loch Ness, starting in an atmospheric moorland setting between Fort Augustus and Foyers."It then continues through&nbspthe stunning Highland scenery along the south-eastern shores of Loch Ness, across the River Ness, finishing in Bught Park in the centre of Inverness."The runners have a wonderful setting to run their best and raise money for the Poppy Pledge, marking 100 years since the end of WWI."The Baxters Loch Ness Marathon features several different events, with a 10k, 5k, corporate challenges and the Wee Nessie race for those under the age of five.Poppyscotland provides a number of services to former members of the armed forces across the country, including direct financial assistance, advice and supported employment.The charity also offers veterans a drop-in service at the MacRobert Centre on Strothers Lane in Inverness.It has taken part in a number of initiatives in recent months, including the Hearing Forces campaign to help veterans with hearing problems.The charity also launched the&nbspCount Them In scheme, which was backed by cross-party MSPs at Holyrood and aims to close a "knowledge gap" in the census to identify utilities which are needed by ex-servicemen and women.Poppyscotland has previously estimated that there could be in the region of 100,000 ex-service personnel currently living in the Highlands.Monday 23 Jul 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Sales pitch provokes Culloden campaigner
story: &nbspIT was salt in the wounds for a leading objector to homes being built near the sacred Culloden battlefield site &ndash receiving a glossy sales brochure for the site from the house builders.John McCulloch, the keeper of the 1745 Association Library, was left fuming.Having failed in a quest, backed by thousands of people across the globe, to block Kirkwood Homes&rsquo 16-house development at Viewhill, he has now received the company' sales pitch explaining how the luxury four and five-bedroom detached homes are "selling fast".Mr McCulloch, who lives in East Lothian, said: "They had the cheek to send me an email to see if I wanted to buy a house. I was totally disgusted with them."The only way they&rsquove got my email address is from me putting in the protest about them wanting to build at Culloden."More and more people are submitting planning proposals to build on Culloden battlefield and I&rsquom disgusted with them. It' all about money."They have no absolutely appreciation of the history of the place. What it says to me is that they don&rsquot care if they build on people' graves."Mr McCulloch (56), who was part of a protest to the Scottish Parliament on the development issue, has emailed Kirkwood Homes to register his "disappointment and disgust".He asked: "Have you no respect for the dead? Culloden Battlefield is a war grave. Bodies from both sides lie under the ground there."There are lots of other places to build your houses in Inverness."I am a patriot of Scotland and your email had such an effect on me you ruined my day. Please do not send me any more emails."He insisted he would never quit his campaigning to protect the surrounding area."I&rsquom a Scotsman, through and through, I&rsquom for independence and I just feel you can&rsquot build on battlefields," he said.A spokeswoman for Kirkwood Homes said: "In order to receive our marketing emails, an individual must register their email address through a specific development page or contact us page through our website."As a result of the recent GDPR legislation, individuals are now in control of their own data &ndash therefore must directly unsubscribe to unwanted marketing emails."Inverness South councillor Ken Gowans, who pressed for the creation of a buffer zone to deter development around the battlefield, doubted the email was vindictive."These things happen. We all receive unsolicited mail from time to time. It' how modern marketing systems work," he said.The Viewhill scheme won planning permission on appeal in 2014.Monday 23 Jul 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Schoolgirls inspiring bid to wipe out racism
story: &nbspA DETERMINED eight-year-old has been praised after taking an inspirational stand against racism in her community by personally removing a vile message she found defacing a local mural.Breagha Gowans spotted the anti-Muslim slur scribbled on the wall of an underpass near Culloden Wood while out for a walk with her mother Michelle.After the pair had a chat about what exactly the message &ndash which the Courier will not print &ndash meant, the youngster decided to step up and take it upon herself to erase it, gathering a bag full of cleaning equipment for the job."I wanted to clean up the graffiti because I have a friend at school who is Muslim and I didn&rsquot want her to be upset," she said."I wanted to be kind towards others."The underpass where Breagha spotted the graffiti passes below Barn Church Road and is covered in a colourful mural in a deliberate bid to dissuade would-be vandals from defacing the walls.After scrubbing the wall clean again, she appealed to everyone to show more respect towards those around them."Please don&rsquot do it because it is hateful and no-one likes bullies," she said."It isn&rsquot good to hurt people' feelings and I didn&rsquot like to see something that would make someone feel bad."Breagha' father is Inverness South councillor Ken Gowans who said he was proud of the way she had decided to tackle the problem head-on."I told her it was fantastic &ndash though like a typical eight-year-old she was off doing something else," he said."Breagha and her class have been learning about different religions at Inshes Primary School and she has a very strong sense of justice and fairness."It is a testament to what they are teaching in school. They are brought up without prejudice and know more than the bigot who wrote the graffiti."A spokesman for Inverness Mosque, Waheed Khan, was touched to hear of Breagha' actions."We commend this girl for going out of her way to clean this up," he said, adding that graffiti of the nature she witnessed was offensive to everyone, whether Muslim or not.Praising her for her "bravery" in taking a stand and highlighting the problem of offensive graffiti in general, he added: "The wider community of Inverness is very tolerant and kind towards us and it is very good to highlight good things like this."A Police Scotland spokesman said the force had not received a complaint about the graffiti but warned that "vandalism is unacceptable, no matter what form it takes" and that wherever offenders were identified, they would be "robustly dealt with".He added: "Police Scotland urges people not to tolerate vandalism or anti-social behaviour but to report them by calling 101 as promptly as possible."A spokesman for Highland Council said: "Vandalism and or graffiti of council-owned property should be reported to Highland Council by either phoning the service centre on 01349 886606 or by using the 24/7 online reporting forms on our website at www.highland.gov.uk/report."Crimes should be reported to Police Scotland on 101."Monday 23 Jul 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Serios road accident near Ullapool road closed in both directions
story: A SERIOUS road accident has occurred south of Ullapool and police have closed the road in both directions.The incident happened at around 2.30pm on the A835 just north of the junction with the A832 at Corrieshalloch Gorge.It is understood that a motorcycle has collided with a car.Traffic is being diverted via Lairg.Motorists are being asked to avoid the area if possible.&nbspA Scottish Ambulance Service spokesperson said: &ldquoWe received a call at 1433 hours on Thursday 19 July to attend a road traffic collision on the A835 near Ullapool.&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&ldquoWe dispatched one ambulance and are still currently on scene.Calmac Ferries, which runs a service between Ullapool and Stornoway is holding the vessel in the meantime for motorists who are making their way to the ferry.A notice on its website reads: "Due to a serious accident on the A835 outside Ullapool, the road is currently closed and traffic is being diverted via Lairg, which will add one and a half hours to the journey."Ullapool port will hold the vessel for a period of time until more information is provided."Monday 23 Jul 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Sweet success leads to relocation plan
story: A BUSINESS that began life on a couple' kitchen table in Nairn has grown so much that Tipsy Unicorn creators Melissa Sutherland and husband Tibor Bandula are having to move to meet demand for their alcohol flavoured jellies.However, Melissa hopes their relocation south will not be permanent."It' probably only temporary, but for the next year or two we will be in Edinburgh so we can grow a bit quicker," Melissa revealed."We needed some space and it was the only place we could find that had some, so we are moving &ndash for a little bit at least."Melissa and Tibor set up Tipsy Unicorn Sweets as a business they could run from home, allowing Melissa to care for the couple' two young children, and put her passion for sweets, cocktails and cooking to good use."I think we knew it would be somewhat popular and at least be interesting, but we didn&rsquot expect that we would be growing so quickly in our first year," Melissa said."My kids are still at home with me pretty much full time and I get to stay at home with them while doing my work, so it' not bad. We plan everything around the family &ndash but it is hard work."Initially available at local outlets, including Brodie Countryfare, as the Tipsy Unicorn range has grown, demand from wholesalers and online sales has also increased.Helping Melissa and Tibor meet the growing demand for their alcoholic sweets is a &pound10,000 award from Scottish Edge, the entrepreneurial initiative which offers successful applicants a share of more than &pound1 million in funding to help their businesses grow.The Tipsy Unicorn award, one of seven Young Edge grants awarded to applicants under 30, will be invested in a new packaging machine to speed up the production process .It will also help the couple to take on a new employee within the next three months.Tipsy Unicorn' adults-only cocktail inspired sweets are made with local produce as much as possible, as well as generous helpings of fruit and alcohol.Flavours produced so far include Tipsy Unicorn' own spin on lounge bar favourites tropical daiquiri, limoncello, pina colada and Prosecco and raspberry, as well as a collaboration with Caithness' Rock Rose gin, but fans of their unique products can look forward to an even wider choice."We&rsquore barely able to keep up with demand as it is, but we are actually adding two new flavours, apple martini and whisky Manhattan," Melissa revealed."We&rsquore also working on a top secret project."We can&rsquot say much about it at the moment, but when it comes out I think it will be pretty good &ndash and people will like it!"Monday 23 Jul 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Timing of key bridge closure branded baffling
story: &nbsp"BAFFLED" councillors have hit out at plans to shut a key access to a popular Inverness beauty spot for up to six weeks at the height of the tourist season.The suspension bridge linking Bught Road with Whin Island will close this Monday for "essential repairs" as part of wider refurbishment of footpaths within the Ness Islands.The move will temporarily cut off access to the beauty spot from the west side of the River Ness at a time when visitor numbers are at their highest.And that decision has sparked questions from puzzled councillors, who have asked why work is beginning now &ndash 13 months after the cash for it was signed off and three months after work elsewhere on the latest phase got underway.They have also criticised the short one week notice period given to the public.Inverness West councillor Alex Graham, said: "It was very disappointing that [the public] were given such short notice of the work, particularly because it is used as the main access to the Ness Islands from the Bught side [of the river] and of course it' also part of the Great Glen Way route as well so it' important to tourists as well as locals."I accept that the work is necessary and has to be done and I&rsquove been in touch with the council to see if work can be done as quickly as possible and in less than six weeks."But I&rsquom a bit baffled as to why it has taken so long [to start], as there was approval in June 2017 for an extra &pound73k for work on the bridges."Why has it taken a year between then and the work?"Inverness Central councillor Bet McAllister also raised concerns, and highlighted the impact the closure could have on people heading to and from local events, such as the open air Little Mix concert on Sunday, July 29.She added that if the work needed settled weather and low river levels, it could have been carried out months before now thanks to the exceptionally dry spring and summer the Highlands has experienced."I can&rsquot understand it," she said. "Why not start in April or early May &ndash they could have had it done."I&rsquom not happy with the timing, especially when we&rsquove had such good weather. They could&rsquove saved lots of hassle if they&rsquod just got on with it."Someone probably needs to get their knuckles rapped. It' such bad timing. If it was that dangerous and bad why not carry out the work before. And if it' not dangerous why not leave it [to a quieter time]?""They could easily do it in September."Highland Council insisted the timing was due to the need for a settled weather window, and that the Monday start date was designed to avoid this weekend' Inverness Highland Games.A spokeswoman said: "The council apologises for any inconvenience that this will cause and is mindful of the fact that the closure is taking place throughout the summer, however the works are necessary for the essential maintenance of the bridge and the closure is for public safety."The timing of the refurbishment in the summer season is necessary as it provides the best weather conditions to get the work done safely with lower river levels."Meanwhile, the council has urged the public to stop attaching so-called &lsquolove locks&rsquo to bridges, and plans to remove any it finds during the repair work. It also called on people not to place stickers on lamps, benches or bridges."The padlocks cause rust and both stickers and padlocks damage paintwork," they said. "All existing padlocks and stickers will be removed as part of the refurbishment works and the council' plea is to leave no trace."Monday 23 Jul 2018 3:35 AM&nbsp&nbsp
